Ayssi comensan las paraulas de Albucasim .	Thus begin the words of Albucasis.
O, filhs, pus yeu he a vos complit aquest libre, le qual es le derier de la sciencia de medicina, per le compliment de lu so consequit la fi en lu, e per las exposicios de lu, e per las declaracios de lu, es a mi vist que yeu complesca aquel a vos am aquest tractat, le qual es partida de la operacio am ma, so es cyrurgia.	O, son, since I have completed for you this book, which is the culmination of the science of medicine,  through its completion, and through its explanations, and through its clarifications, it seems to me that I should complete this for you with this treatise, which is a part of manual operation, that is, surgery.
Quar la operacio am ma es prostrada en nostre regio e en nostre temps de tot privada, entro que fort leu peric la sciencia de lu, e le vistigi de lu es ostat; e no romasero de lu sino alcunas petitas descripcios en les libres dels Antics, les quals mudero las mas e endevenc ad aquels error e heyssitacio entro que son clausas las entencios de lu e es elonguada la forsa de lu e l’art.	Because manual operation is neglected in our region and in our time, almost entirely deprived, so that the science of it is in great peril, and its practice is lost; and there remains of it only some small descriptions in the books of the Ancients, which are mostly corrupted and thus lead to error and hesitation, so that its intentions are obscured and its strength and art are weakened.
E es vist a mi que yeu vivifique aquela am ordenacio de aquest tractat en aquela segon la via de exposicio e de declaracio e de abreviacio; e per que vengua am las formas dels ferramentz de cautheri e dels autres instrumentz de la obra cum sia per addicio de la declaracio, e per preparacio de lu, la qual causa es necessaria.	And it seems to me that I should revive it with the ordering of this treatise, following the path of explanation, clarification, and abbreviation; and so that it comes with the forms of cautery instruments and other surgical instruments, as is appropriate, through the addition of clarification, and through their preparation, which is a necessary matter.
Mays la causa per la qual no es atrobat bo artifex am la sieua ma en aquest nostre temps, es quar la art de medicina es longua, e que cove le sieu actor denant aquo esser excercitat en la sciencia de anotomia la qual recontec Gualia entro que sapia les juvament dels membres e las formas de aquels, e la conjunctio e la separacio de lor; e haia la conoyssensa dels osses, dels nervis e dels lacertz, e·l nombre de aquels, e la egrecio de lor; e de las venas pulsatils e de las quietas, e dels locs del eyssiment de lor.	But the reason why a skilled artisan with his hands is not found in our time is that the art of medicine is lengthy, and it is necessary for its practitioner beforehand to be trained in the science of anatomy, which is quite difficult, so that he knows the functions of the limbs and their forms, and their connections and separations; and he should have knowledge of the bones, nerves, and muscles, and their number and location; and of the pulsating and quiet veins, and the places of their emergence.
E per aquo ditz Ypocras que am u nom es mot, mays en l’obra petit, e majorment en la art de la ma.	And for this reason Hippocrates says that in name it is much, but in practice little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Mays nos ja avem dit de aquel en l’introit de aquest libre; quar qui no es scient aquo que li avem dit de anotomia, no es evacuat que no caia en error per la qual siran mortz les homes, ayssi cum yeu he vist trops de aquels, quar alscus son formatz en esta sciencia e gettan se de aquela ses sciencia e ses experiment.	But we have already spoken of this in the introduction to this book; for he who is not knowledgeable in what we have said about anatomy is not exempt from falling into error by which men will die, as I have seen many such cases, for some are trained in this science and practice it without knowledge and without experience.
Quar yeu vi un metge folh e enperit aver incidit un apostema escrophilos en le colh de una femna, e incidic alcunas arterias del colh per que fluic gran sanc entro que la femna cazec morta entre las mas de lu.	For I saw a foolish and reckless physician incise a scrofulous abscess in the neck of a woman, and he incised some arteries of the neck, so that a great deal of blood flowed until the woman died in his hands.
E vi un autre metge que pres que el traguera una peyra d’un home le qual avia procesit en sa etat, e la peyra era gran, e venguet a lu e trayssec aquela peyra am un tros de la vesiqua, per que aquel home al tertz dia es mort.	And I saw another physician who undertook to remove a stone from a man who was elderly, and the stone was large, and he came to him and extracted that stone with a piece of the bladder, so that that man died on the third day.
E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira.	And I was called to extract it, and I saw that because of the size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I knew that he would die.
E vi un autre metge le qual prenia stipendic de un duc de nostra terra per cyrurgia, e endeven a un crastrat negre le qual era deves lu fractura en la coyssa de lu; e perparec le metge am la sua ignorancia, estrayssec la fractura, sobre la plagua, am pulvinas e astelas am forta strectura, e no layssec a la plagua espiracio.	And I saw another physician who received a stipend from a duke of our land for surgery, and it happened that a black slave who was under him suffered a fracture in his thigh; and the physician, in his ignorance, extracted the fracture, over the wound, with cushions and splints with tight binding, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
E aprop le desliet segons los sieus desiriers, e aprop le relieg, e aprop le leyssec per alcus jorns e comandec que nos deslies le liament; e estec ayssi entro que la coyssa e·l pe foro apostematz, e pervenguet a perdicio.	And then he unbound it according to his wishes, and then he bound it again, and then he left it like that for some days and commanded that we not unbind the bandage; and it remained so until the thigh and foot were suppurated, and it resulted in loss (of the limb/life).
E yeu fuy apelat a lu, e aparelhegui a desliar le liament, e conseguida es tranquilitat e enayssi amermet de sas dolors.	And I was called to him, and I prepared to unbind the bandage, and tranquility was achieved, and thus a lessening of his pains.
Mays empero ja corrupcio era confermada en le membre, per que no pogui refrenar aquela, e no cessec perambular la corrupcio en le membre entro que·l malaute peric.	But however, corruption was already confirmed in the limb, so that I could not restrain it, and the corruption did not cease to spread in the limb until the patient perished.
E vi un autre metge le qual perforec un apostema cancros, e fo ulcerat aprop alscus dias, entro que foc magnificada la malicia de lu am lo senhor de lu.	And I saw another physician who perforated a cancerous abscess, and it was ulcerated after some days, until its malignancy was magnified by its lord (i.e., the condition worsened greatly).
La qual causa es quar le cranc caut es pur de humor melencolic, lahoras no cove que pervengua a lu am ferr de tot, sino que sia an membre le qual suffertes que de tot fos hostat.	Which is why, because the burning cancer is full of melancholic humor, then it is not suitable that it be approached with iron at all, but that it be in a limb which suffers so that it is entirely contained (or, that it be in a limb that can be entirely removed).
E per aquo, filhs, necessari es a vos que la operacio am ma sia devisada en dos devesios: so es en operacio a lu qual es associada salut, e en obra am la qual es perilh en las majors disposicios.	And therefore, sons, it is necessary for you that the operation with the hand be divided into two divisions: that is, into an operation which is associated with health, and into a work in which there is peril in the greatest circumstances (or, in the most serious cases).
E yeu ja he exsitat aquo en tot loc de aquest libre en le qual venc opperacio en la qual es error e temor; per que necessari es a vos que guardetz aquo e layssetz aquel, per que les folhs no atrobo via a parlar e a vos desonestar.	And I have already explained this in every part of this book, in which operations come which contain error and fear; therefore it is necessary for you that you guard against this and leave that (i.e., avoid those operations), lest fools find a way to speak and dishonor you.
E donc prenetz las vostras armas am sollicitut e am proteccio de Dieu , e les vostres malautes am falicitat e am fermetat.	And therefore, take up your instruments with diligence and with God's protection, and treat your patients with happiness and firmness.
E usatz de la milhor via per la gracia de Dieu perdusent a salut e a lausabla successio, e laysatz las malautias terriblas de difficil sanacio, e ostatz las vostras armas de aquo que vos fa temer, per so que ysitatio en vostra fe e en le vostre nom no vos evasisca: quar mays es remanent a la vostra gloria, e pus aut en le mon e en derier a las vostras sanctitatz.	And use the best method, by the grace of God, leading to health and praiseworthy success, and leave the terrible diseases of difficult healing, and abstain from those things that cause you fear, so that wavering in your faith and in your reputation does not overtake you: for it remains more for your glory, and higher in the world and behind your holiness.
Gualia ja diyssec en alcunas sieuas monicios:	Galen already said in some of his admonitions:
“No mediquetz malautia mala, per so que mals metges no siatz nompnatz”.	Do not treat a bad disease, lest you be called a bad physician.
E yeu ja he devesit aquest libre segontz tres capitols.	And I have divided this book into three chapters.
Comensa la divisio del libre, e primier de la primieyra partida.	Begins the division of the book, and first of the first part.
Le primier capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, en las formas dels instrumentz e en les ferrementz dels cauteris, e de aquo que necessari es en la opperacio.	The first chapter deals with the head down to the feet, the forms of instruments and cautery tools, and what is necessary in the operation.
La divisio de la segonda partida.	The division of the second part.
Le segon capitol, de siccio e perforacio, e de ventosas, e de plaguas, e de extractio de sagetas e de semblantz ad aquelas, tot capitolat e ordenat de las formas dels instrumentz.	The second chapter, on suction and perforation, and on cupping glasses, and on wounds, and on the extraction of arrows and similar things, all chaptered and ordered according to the forms of the instruments.
Divisio de la tersa partida.	Division of the third part.
Le tertz capitol, de restauracio e de dislocacio, e de curacio de torcio e de semblantz ad aquels; capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, e de las formas dels instrumentz.	The third chapter, on reduction and dislocation, and on the treatment of sprains and similar things; a chapter ordered from head to foot, and on the forms of the instruments.
De cauteri am foc e am medicina aguda e rememoracio de la opperacio.	Of cautery with fire and with sharp medicine and remembrance of the operation.
Am aquel comensa le tractat de tot le libre.	With this begins the treatise of the whole book.
Cove que yeu digua la qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri e dels noccumentz de lu, e en qual compleccio sia prohibit cauteri.	It is necessary that I describe the qualities of the benefits of this cautery and its drawbacks, and in what constitution cautery is prohibited.
Donc dic que·l sermo de la qualitat del juvament de cauteri e del noccument de lu es sermo lonc e prolixs, e subtil per sciensa, e secret amaguat; e ja de lu a parlat gran multitut de savis, e de lu se son desacordatz, et a mi abasta un petit dels sermons de lor, temen perlonguacio.	Therefore I say that the discourse on the quality of the benefit of cautery and its drawbacks is a long and prolix discourse, and subtle in science, and a hidden secret; and many wise men have already spoken of it, and they have disagreed about it, and a small part of their discourses suffices for me, fearing prolixity.
E donc dic que cauteri comfereys a tota compleccio universalment la qual es am materia o ses materia, exceptat dos compleccios, las quals son compleccios caudas ses materia .	And therefore I say that cautery benefits all complexions universally, whether with matter or without matter, except for two complexions, which are cold complexions without matter.
En la compleccio cauda e secca am materia se desecordero; quar alcus dyssero que cauteri es juvatiu ad aquela, e les autres dyssero le contrari de aquel, que cauteri no es convenient en malautia la qual es per qualiditat e per siccitat, quar natura del foc es qualiditat e siccitat, e enconvenient es que malautia cauda e secca am aquo que es caut e sec sia sanada.	In the hot and dry complexion with matter there is disagreement; for some say that cautery is beneficial to it, and others say the contrary, that cautery is not suitable for a disease which is caused by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat and dryness, and it is inconvenient that a hot and dry disease should be healed with something that is hot and dry.
E diysec aquel que ditz le contrari de aquel, que per cauteri es fayt juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca que ve en les cors dels homes, quar quan tu comparas le cors de home e las humiditatz de lu a la compleccio del foc, atrobas le cors de home freg.	And I contradict those who say the contrary, that benefit is achieved through cautery in every hot and dry disease that occurs in the human body, because when you compare the human body and its humors to the complexion of fire, you find the human body cold.
E yeu dic per le sermo de aquel, que esperiment aquo ja a mi alscunas vetz a descubert.	And I say, regarding this discourse, that experience has revealed this to me several times.
Mays empero no cove que vengua sobre aquo aquel que ja es exproat e excersitat en le capitol de cauteri per derier exercici, e a conogut la diversitat de la compleccio dels homes e la disposicio de las malautias en lor meteyssas, e las causas de aquelas, e·ls accidentz de lor, e l’espasi del temps de aquelas.	However, it is not fitting that this should come from someone who has already been exhausted and exercised in the chapter on cautery by prior practice, and who has understood the diversity of human complexions and the disposition of diseases in themselves, and the causes of those, and their accidents, and the duration of those.
Mays en las autras compleccios, no es sobre vos temor, e majorment en las malautias fregas e humidas, quar ja totz les metges se son acordatz sobre aquels, e no so desecordatz en le juvament am cauteri en aquelas.	But in other complexions, there is no fear for you, and especially in cold and humid diseases, because all physicians are agreed on those, and they do not disagree on the benefit of cautery in them.
E sapiatz, filhs, que del secret de curacio per cauteri am foc e de la bontat de lu, so sobre cauteri am medicina comburent, es quar le foc es simple, la accio del qual no perven sino al membre le qual es cauterizat e no notz al autre membre am lu ajustat sino am petit nocument.	And know, sons, that the secret of healing by cautery with fire, and its goodness, is superior to cautery with burning medicine, because fire is simple, whose action does not reach beyond the member which is cauterized and does not harm the other members adjacent to it except with little harm.
Mays la accio de medicina comburent perven ad aquel en les membres le qual de lu alunhat, e fort leu fa venir en le membre malautia de dificil sanacio e fort leu ausit.	But the action of burning medicine reaches those members which are distant from it, and quickly brings about in the member a disease of difficult healing and quickly kills.
Mays le foc, per la sua sublimitat e de la sua substancia bontat, no fa aquo sino que superfluisca E ja es a nos conogut per experiment e per longitut de servitut de studi am l’art sobre le veritat de las causas; e per aquo yeu so excusat de la longitut del sermo E si no fos que no es legut al mieu libre en aquest pausero a vos secret amaguat am le foc, e la qualitat de la operacio de lu en les cors e de la sieua expulcio per la qual expellis las malautias, am sermo philosophic demostratiu, le qual siria acuit en las vostras pessas.	But fire, by its sublimity and the goodness of its substance, does not do this except to remove superfluities. And it is known to us by experiment and by long service of study with the art concerning the truth of the causes; and therefore I am excused from the length of discourse. And if it were not that it is not written in my book in this place to reveal to you this secret concerning fire, and the quality of its operation in the bodies and its expulsion by which it expels illnesses, with philosophical demonstrative discourse, which would be difficult to understand in your minds.
E sapiatz, filhs, que els se desacordan del temps en le qual es convenient far cauteri e pausan le milhor temps de primaveyra.	And know, sons, that they disagree on the time in which it is convenient to perform cautery, and they posit springtime as the best time.
E yeu dic que cauteri es convenient en tot temps, per so que le nocument per le temps accident es submergit en le juvament de aquo que am le cauteri es atirat, e majorment si le cauteri es per dolors o de dolors necessaries, fortz e fistinas, las quals no suffertan tarditat per so que es temut de aquelas que vengua malicia, que es major que petit nocument entrant per lo temps.	And I say that cautery is convenient at all times, because the harm caused by accidental timing is overwhelmed by the benefit which is obtained by cautery, and especially if the cautery is for necessary, strong and sudden pains, which do not allow for delay because it is feared that those pains might become worse, which is a greater harm than a small harm introduced by timing.
E aysso no catz en vostras pessas, o, filhs, aquo no estiman sino le poble vulguar e les fols metges, so es que ad aquela malautia que es sanada per cauteri no es redicio tot temps, e pausan aquel consequen.	And this does not enter your minds, O sons, this is only considered by the vulgar people and foolish physicians, that is to say that for that illness which is cured by cautery, there is no unsuitable time, and they posit that consequence.
E la causa no es ges ayssi quo els cuydan per aquo, quar cauteri no es sino en loc de medicina la qual altera la compleccio e esicca las humiditatz las quals son causa per que veno las dolors.	And the cause is not at all as they believe, for cautery is only in the place of a medicine which alters the complexion and dries the humors which are the cause of the pains.
Mays empero cauteri superflueys sobre la medicina per volicitat de la sua valitut e vertut de la sua operacio e grandesa del sieu senhor.	However, cautery is superfluous over medicine because of the swiftness of its efficacy and the power of its operation and the greatness of its effect.
E es possible que la sua malautia retorne en alcuna hora del temps, segon la compleccio del malaute e la locacio de la sua malautia, e la vertut de lu, e aquo que es preparat en le cors de lu de la agreguacio de las superfluitatz en lu, e aquo que es pervengut a lu en la sua acquisicio en viandas e semblantz de aquelas causas; sino que la malautia en la qual sia aministrat cauteri sia malautia subtil en membre de paucas superfluitatz e humiditatz, ayssi cum cauteri de dent per dolor e semblantz ad aquel, possible es que en lu no retorne aquela dolor, mays aquo se fa en petitz.	And it is possible that the illness may return at some time, according to the complexion of the patient and the location of the illness, and the strength of the patient, and what is prepared in the patient's body from the aggregation of superfluities within, and what has been acquired by the patient through diet and similar causes; but if the illness to which cautery is administered is a subtle illness in a limb with few superfluities and humors, as is cautery of a tooth for pain and similar cases, it is possible that the pain will not return, but this happens rarely.
E mays sermo vulgar es que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, e es sermo dreyturier, no ad aquo que els entendo en lu, quar els crezo que no es curacio que aprofieyta am medicina ni am autra causa aprop cauteri.	And it is more common speech that cautery is the last resort of medicine, and this is a true saying, not in the sense that they understand it, for they believe that it is not a cure that profits with medicine or any other cause except cautery.
E la causa es en contrari de aquo; e la entencio que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina no es sino quan administram las manieyras de curacio en alcunas malautias, e aquelas medicinas no conferieysso, e aprop en la fi de la causa aministra hom cauteri, e aprofieyta ad aquela.	And the cause is contrary to that; and the intention that cautery is the last resort of medicine is only when we administer methods of cure in certain illnesses, and those medicines do not help, and then at the end of the treatment, one administers cautery, and it helps in that case.
E lahoras de aqui cat16 que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, no segon la entencio la qual entendo les vulgars e trops dels fols metges.	And therefore, from this it is understood that cautery is the last resort of medicine, not according to the understanding of the common people and many foolish doctors.
E diyssero les antics que cauteri am aur es milhor que cauteri am ferr, e no diyssero aquo sino per la equalitat del aur e sublimitat de la sua sustancia.	And the ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron, and they did not say this except for the evenness of gold and the sublimity of its substance.
E diyssero que le loc de cauteri no fa brac, cum aquo no sia absolutament vertat, quar yeu ja he aquo proat e he atrobat que aquel no fa aquo sino en alcus cors ses les autres, e cauteri am aquel es bo e milhor que am ferr ayssi quo els diyssero; mays empero quan tu fas cauteri am foc am de aur, no es a tu declarat, quar es egnit segon la quantitat que tu vols per la rugor de l’aur, e quar prepara a recebre freg; e si ajustas sobre lu ignicio se fon l’aur per le foc, e caso en le foc alcunas laminas per que le artifex catz per la occupacio de aquel.	And they said that the place of cautery does not scar, although that is not entirely true, for I have already proven this and found that it does not do so except in some bodies and not others, and cautery with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said; however, when you do cautery with fire with gold, it is not clear to you, because it is heated according to the quantity you want by the roughness of the gold, and because it prepares to receive cold; and if you apply too much heat, the gold melts from the fire, and some laminae fall into the fire, causing the craftsman trouble from this.
E per aquo es fayt cauteri am ferr deves nos pus leugerament e pus propdanament a rectitut de operacio.	And because of this, cautery with iron is done more easily and more readily with precision of operation.
E yeu ja he ordenat aquest capitol en le cauteri segon capitols, et he ordenat aquels del cap entro les pes, per so que aleugo le demandant aquo que vol de lu.	And I have already ordered this chapter on cautery according to chapters, and I have ordered those from the head down to the feet, so that I might explain to the one asking what he wants from it.
De cauteri de dolor de cap per frigiditat e humiditat.	Of cautery for headache due to coldness and dampness.
Le capitol primier.	The first chapter.
Aquesta cauterizacio confereys a la humiditat e frigiditat sobre le servel accident de la qual so doas causas, so es causa de soda e multitut de flux raumatic, apelat corissa, del cap a las partidas dels huelhs e de las aurelhas fluent, e multitut de dormir, e de dolor de dentz e del guolayro, e universalment de tota malautia que ve per fregiditat, ayssi cum paraliticament, sodo e apoplexio, e semblantz en aquelas malautias.	This cauterization is applied to dampness and coldness on the brain; the accidents of which are two causes: that is, a cause of sudden and profuse rheumatic flux, called coryza, flowing from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and excessive sleepiness, and toothache and sore throat, and universally any illness that comes from coldness, such as paralysis, sudden stroke (apoplexy), and similar illnesses.
La forma de aquesta cauterizacio es aquesta, que primieyrament comandes al malaute que sia evacuat am medicina lacsativa le cap mondificant, per tres o per quatre nueytz, segon que exhigeys la vertut del malaute e la edat de lu e la sua costuma.	The method of this cauterization is this: first, order the patient to be evacuated with purgative medicine, cleansing the head, for three or four nights, depending on the strength of the patient, his age, and his constitution.
E aprop comanda li que raza le sieu cap am razor, e aprop fay aquel sezer entre las tuas mas sobre una banca cayrada e que pause las suas mas sobre le pietz sieu.	Then order him to shave his head with a razor, and then have him sit between your hands on a low bench and place his hands on his feet.
E aprop pausa la razit de la tua palma aprop le pous sobre la razit del nas entre les huels sieus.	And then place the root of your palm near the  [likely meaning:  a specific point near] the bridge of the nose between his eyes.
Mays empero, cum le tieu dit del mieg loc es pervengut, signa aquel loc am tenta, e aprop igneys le cauteri olivar del qual aquesta es la forma:	However, when your middle finger has reached that point, mark the spot with ink, and then ignite the olive cautery, of which this is the form:
E aprop pausa aquel sobre le loc senhat am tenta, a manieyra que descent, am la qual la tieua ma sia constrengida petit a petit, e tu revolveys aquel.	And then place that [the cautery] on the spot marked with ink, in such a way that it descends, with which your hand is gradually constrained, and you revolve it.
E aprop leva la tua ma leugerament e reguarda le loc, e si veses ja del os esser descubert alcuna quantitat del cap, ayssi cum la quantitat de gra de errs, lahoras eleva la tua ma, e si no torno la tua ma am aquel ferr, am autre de aquel, si es enfrigidat, entro que sia vist del os aquo que yeu he dit a tu.	And then lift your hand slightly and observe the place, and if you see some quantity of the head of the bone uncovered, like the size of a grain of barley, then lift your hand, and if not, return your hand with that iron, or with another like it if this one is cooled, until that which I have told you is seen of the bone.
E aprop pren un petit de sal e disolveys aquel sobre le loc e leyssa aquel per tres jorns.	And then take a little salt and dissolve it on the location and leave it for three days.
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto enbegut en boder e leyssa aquel sobre lu entro que sia destrusida la scara del foc.	And then place on it cotton soaked in vinegar and leave it there until the burn scar is destroyed.
E aprop cura le loc am anguent tetrafarmacon entro que sia sanat.	And then treat the area with tetrafarmacon ointment until it is healed.
E ja diyssero que quant la plagua roman uberta, tant mielhs geta le brac, per que es milhor e mays juvatiu.	And it has been said that when the wound remains open, it better discharges the arm, because it is better and more beneficial.
E diyssero alcus de lor que sia cauterizada la codena entro al os, e sia tengut le cauteri entro que sia adhurida alcuna partida de la specitut del os.	And some of them say that the elbow should be cauterized to the bone, and the cautery should be held there until some part of the bone's substance is hardened/burned.
E aprop sia ras aquo que es adhust del os, e aprop sia curat.	And then scrape away what is burned from the bone, and then let it be healed.
E diyssero autres que am lo cauteri pervengua al derier, entro que enprema en le os forta enprecio entro que le os caga, e aquesta es la forma de alphecati petit:	And others say that with the cautery, penetrate to the back, until it firmly penetrates the bone, until the bone is charred, and this is the manner of a small ulcer.
E estiman de aquel loc expiran la vapors del cap.	And they believe that vapors from the head exhale from that place.
E sia tenguda la plagua uberta per lonc temps, e aprop sia curada entro que sia consolidada.	And let the wound be kept open for a long time, and then let it be healed until it is consolidated.
Mays a mi no so vistas aquestas doas specias de cauteri de tot, sino en alcus homes segon via de temor; e layssa aquel, deves mi, milhor es am salut, quan es; quar le cap es develitat per solucio de continuitat de lu ayssi cum havem testificat en les autres membres, e majorment quan le cap del malaute es de freul natura.	But I have not seen these two types of cautery at all, except in some men, as a method of fear; and leave that, it seems to me, better is health when it is; for the head is weakened by the solution of its continuity, as we have testified in the other members, and especially when the patient's head is of a cold nature.
E la specia de cauteri primieyra es mays salva e milhor deves mi; e de aquela husi e am aquela obra am salut.	And the first type of cautery is safer and better, in my opinion; and with that I use and with that I work for health.
Capitol segon.	Chapter two.
Del cauteri del cap.	Concerning the cautery of the head.
Quan en tot le cap accideys dolor cronica e longua e aquo es en le malaute prolonguat, e usa de gerras e de cochias e de capipurges e de emplaustres e de guatz e de cadels e de gualinas e de semblantz, e majorment si ja es cauterizat am un cautere le qual recontam e no aprofieyta a lu deguna de aquelas causas, lahoras considera quar si le cap del malaute es de fort creacio en la sua natura; e no es freul et atroba mot gran freg, lahoras aquel cauterisa am autra cauteri dejos aquel un pauc.	When chronic and prolonged pain occurs throughout the head, and this is prolonged in the patient, and he uses leeches and cupping and purgatives and plasters and poultices and cauteries and unguents and similar things, and especially if he has already been cauterized with a cautery which we recount and none of those things benefit him, then consider whether the patient's head is of strong constitution by nature; and if it is not weak and finds much great cold, then cauterize that with another cautery a little below that one.
E aprop cauterisa aquel sobre le corn del sieu cap am cauteri entro que la codena es partida.	And then cauterize that above the temple of his head with a cautery until the scab is formed.
Incisa la codena e sia descuberta del os la quantitat la qual havem recontat e cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en la partida deriera del cap en le loc le qual es apelat vas, — e es aquel loc en le qual es pausada ventosa.	Incise the scab and let the bone be uncovered to the extent that we have recounted, and cauterize that with a cautery in the back part of the head, in the place which is called the vas - and this is the place where a cupping glass is placed.
Et alleuja la tua ma en aysso, e no descobras le os, quar le malaute per aquo atroba mot gran dolor diversa de la dolor de totz les autres cauteris del cap.	And ease your hand in this, and do not uncover the bone, for the patient thereby finds much great pain, different from the pain of all the other cauteries of the head.
E yeu diyre aquest cauteri en son loc, quar cove que·l cauteri am le qual so cauterisatz les corns del cap e le occiput es pus subtil cauteri que aquel am le qual es cauterisat le mieg loc del cap; e aquesta es la forma de lu.	And I say this cautery in its place, because it is necessary that the cautery with which the temples of the head and the occiput are cauterized is a more subtle cautery than that with which the middle part of the head is cauterized; and this is its form.
Capitol ters.	Chapter Three.
De cauterisacio de emigranea no-antiqua.	Concerning the cauterization of a not-ancient migraine.  (or, Concerning the cauterization of a recent migraine.)
Quan endeve en la partida del cap dolor sodo, o es stenduda dolor entro al uelh, sia evacuat am medicinas le cap mondificantz, e sia aministrada l’autra curacio, la qual yeu he dita en las devesios de las malautias; e tot no aprofieyta, lahoras cauterisacio en lu es en dos manieyras: o cauterisacio am medicina acuta comburent, o am ferr.	When a sudden pain occurs in the head, or a spreading pain around the eye, let the head be evacuated with purifying medicines, and let the other treatment be administered, which I have described in the various diseases; and if nothing helps, then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterization with an acute, burning medicine, or with iron.
Mays cauteri am medicina comburent es que tu prenguas una dolsa de alh, e escorgas aquela e abcindas las extremitatz de lu de amdos les caps.	But cauterization with a burning medicine is that you take a clove of garlic, and you crush it and bind its extremities on both sides.
E aprop incideys le loc de la dolor en la templa am una lanceta lada entro que sia en lu feyt loc dejos la codena, entro que sia occultada.	Then incise the location of the pain in the temple with a lancet until a place is made under the skin, so that it is hidden.
E aprop strenh sobre lu am stopada per descent constreccio, e layssa aquel per le spazi de tres horas; e aprop deslia le e tratz le alh, e laysa la plagua per dos o per tres jorn, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto submergit en boder entro que le loc fassa brac.	Then bind it tightly with a bandage for a continuous constriction, and leave it for three hours; then untie it and remove the garlic, and leave the wound for two or three days, then apply a cotton swab soaked in vinegar until the area becomes inflamed.
E aprop cura aquel am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
E si tu voys, fe aquo am alcunas medicinas comburentz las quals yeu he scriutas en le douse tractat de medicinas comburentz.	And if you wish, do this with some burning medicines which I have written about in the twelfth treatise on burning medicines.
Mays la cauterisacio am ferr segon aquesta manieyra: igneys per cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	But cauterization with iron in this manner: heat a cautery iron of which this is the form:
e es apelat claus clavilhs, quar le cap de lu es ayssi cum forma de clavel en le qual es alcuna curvitat, e·n le mieg loc de lu es eminensia petita.	and it is called a nail or peg, because its head is shaped like a nail, which has a certain curvature, and in the middle of it is a small eminence.
E aprop pausa sobre loc de la dolor, e rete la tua ma — per que no sia adhurida la arceria la qual es dejos — e revol le ferr petit a petit am velocitat.	And then place it on the location of the pain, and hold your hand — so that the flesh underneath is not burned — and move the iron little by little with speed.
E si la quantitat de lu que es adhurida per la specitut de la codena ayssi quo la maytat de lu, e elava la tua ma per so que la arteria no sia adhurida la qual es dejos, per so que no vengua flux de sanc.	And if the amount of flesh that is burned is as much as half of it, due to the specific nature of the cautery, then lift your hand so that the artery beneath is not burned, so that there is no flow of blood.
E aprop enbibeys coto en aygua de sal e pausa aquel sobre le loc, e layssa aquel per tres dias; e aprop pausa coto mulhat am boder, e aprop cura am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then soak cotton in salt water and place that on the area, and leave it for three days; and then apply cotton soaked in balm, and then treat with ointment until it is healed.
E si voys, cauterisa am la extremitat del cutellari segon cauteri, e guarda te de incisio de arteria en aquesta emigranea propriament no-antiqua.	And if you wish, cauterize with the tip of the scalpel according to the cautery method, and be careful of cutting the artery in this specific, not-ancient, type of headache.
Capitol quart.	Chapter four.
De cauterizacio d’emigranea antiqua.	On the cauterization of chronic headache.
Quan tu curas emigranea am aquo que havem dit de la curacio precedent, e aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias, e no aprofieyta la curacio, e vezes per la malautia que no abasta a lu aquo que havem dit del primier cauteri am medicina o del cauteri am foc, lahoras cove que tu igniscas le cauteri cutellar entro que sia albificat, pus que significas sobre le loc de la dolor am linha de longuesa de la qual sia la maytat del dit, o quays aquel; e depausa la tua ma per una veguada e strenh aquela entro incidiscas la arceria e pervengua entro al os.	When you treat a headache with what we have said in the preceding treatment, and what we have said in the divisions of diseases, and the treatment is not effective, and sometimes the illness is such that what we have said about the first cauterization with medicine or cauterization with fire is insufficient, then you should heat the cautery knife until it is white-hot, after marking the location of the pain with a line whose length is half a finger, or about that; and place your hand there for a moment and press it until you incise the artery and reach the bone.
Empero necessari es a tu que guardes de la continuacio de la mandibula, la qual es mauguda deves la masticacio, e que le lacert no sia adhurit e le nervi le qual mau aquela, e que no s’endevengua espasme.	However, it is necessary for you to be mindful of the continuation of the jaw, which is moved during mastication, and that the muscle not be injured and the nerve which moves it, and that spasm does not occur.
E si es sobre la custodia e cautela de flux de sanc de l’arteria que es abciza, quar en la abcizio de lu es temor, e majorment ad aquel le qual ignora aquo que fa e no es studios e esproat; e layssa la operacio en lu al comensament.	And if it is about the guarding and caution regarding the flow of blood from the artery that is incised, for there is danger in its incision, and especially for one who is ignorant of what he does and is not studious and experienced; and leaves the operation to him at the beginning.
E yeu vindre am rememoracio del regiment de flux de sanc accident de la arceria segon la sieua manieyra, en le sieu loc de aquest libre.	And I will come to the recollection of the treatment of accidental bleeding from the artery according to its manner, in its place in this book.
E si veses de aquesta malautia que no abaste aquest cauteri e veses le cors del malaute tollerable, cauteriza aquel en le mieg loc del cap ayssi cum havem recontat, e cura la plagua entro que sia sanada.	And if you see from this illness that this cauterization is insufficient and the patient's body is tolerable, cauterize it in the middle of the head as we have recounted, and treat the wound until it is healed.
E si voys, aministra le cauteri le qual havem dit en le capitol de streccio de arceria am cauteri havent dos cotels, e es milhor cauterizacio aquesta e mays conferent.	And if you wish, administer the cautery which we have mentioned in the chapter on the constriction of arteries with a cautery having two blades, and this cauterization is better and more suitable.
Capitol .v.	Chapter 5.
De cauterisacio de las dolors de aurelhas.	Chapter 5: On the cauterization of earaches.
Quan en la aurelha ve dolor per freg e es curat am causas lacsativas e am l’autra curacio la qual he dita en la divisio, e no es remauguda la dolor, lahoras igneys le cauteri, e es aquest le qual ha nom puncta, del qual aquesta es la forma:	When pain in the ear comes from cold and is treated with laxative remedies and with the other treatment which I have mentioned in the division, and the pain is not relieved, then apply the cautery, and this is what is called a "puncta," of which this is the form:
E aprop puncta aprop la ignicio, e sia menat al enviro de tota la aurelha ayssi cum roda es revolguda, o en le circuit de quascuna essemps si la dolor es en quascuna.	And then apply the cautery point by point, and let it be moved around the entire ear as a wheel is turned, or in the circumference of each part if the pain is located in a specific part.
Alonga te am le cauteri de la razit de la aurelha pauc a pauc pus que aias senhat le loc am tenta.	Extend the cautery from the root of the ear little by little after you have marked the place with a probe.
E si le cauteri de detz puntz en tota aurelha, e quays aquela, e aprop cura les locz entro que sian sanatz.	And if the cautery requires ten points in the whole ear, or however many, then treat those places until they are healed.
Capitol .vi.	Chapter 6.
De cauterizacio de turtura.	On the cauterization of a cough.
Turtura la qual es curada e am cauterizacio no es sino de las specias las quals veno per flecma, segon que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias.	A cough which is cured with cauterization is only of those types which come from phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of illnesses.
Esquiva cauterizacio de la specia que endeve per siccacio o per spasme del nervi.	Avoid cauterization of the type of cough that arises from dryness or from a spasm of the nerve.
Quan tu curas aquela specia de turtura am jerras e capipurgi e guarguarismes, e no comfereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas le malaute am tres cauteris: la i deves la razit de la aurelha, e·l segon un petit dejos le sieu templar, e le ters deves la conjunccio de doas labias.	When you treat that type of cough with leeches and purgatives and gargles, and your treatment is not effective, then you should cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, the second a little below the temple, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
E pausa lo tieu cauteri per le contrari de la partida malauta, quar mollificacio no ve sino en la partida que apar sana.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the affected area, for softening only comes to the part that appears healthy.
E la forma de cauterisacio es que cauterizas aquel am le cauteri en le dreyt de la extremitat de la aurelha pus sobirana un petit sobre le corn del cap, e en le templar autre, la longuesa del qual sia segon la longitut del dit pous, e depausa la tua ma am cauteri entro que sia comburida la quantitat de la maytat de la specitut de la codena.	And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize it with the cautery at the very tip of the upper ear, a little above the temple, and another in the temple, the length of which should be according to the length of the little finger, and hold your hand with the cautery until half the thickness of the fingernail is burned.
E aquesta es la forma del cauteri, e es specia del cutellari, la forma del qual es denant mesa.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a type of knife, the form of which is shown above/previously described.
Mays empero pus subtil es que aquel un pauc ayssi co vesas; e cove que cotel en lu de superflua groceza un pauc.	However, it is more subtle if that is done slightly as you see; and it is necessary to cut it with a little less excess thickness.
E aprop cura le loc am aquo que es denant procezit entro que sia sanat.	Then treat the area with what has been previously described until it is healed.
Capitol .vii.	Chapter 7.
De cauterizacio de apoplextia antiqua.	Concerning the cauterization of chronic apoplexy.
Quan apoplextia es antiquada e curas aquela am aquo que havem dit e no confereys la tua medicacio e le malaute no ha febre, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris: sobre totz les corn del sieu cap; e am cauteri e le mieg loc del cap, ayssi cum havem dit; e am cauteri en le coguot.	When apoplexy is chronic and you treat it with what we have said, and your treatment does not help, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize them with four cauteries:  on all four corners of their head; and with a cautery in the middle of the head, as we have said; and with a cautery on the neck.
E la manieyra del cauteri es fayta segon que es desus dit.	And the manner of cauterization is done as described above.
E ja es cauterizat sobre la boca del estomac; e es mays derier; e aprop sia curat am aquo que procezeys.	And it is also cauterized above the mouth of the stomach; and it is better behind; and then let it be treated with what follows.
Capitol .viii.	Chapter 8.
De cauterizacio de obblivio fayta per flacma.	Concerning the cauterization of forgetfulness done by flame.
Cove que sian donatz al malaute en le comensament jerras grans e pilulas le servel mondificantz.	So that large enemas and purifying pills are given to the patient at the beginning.
E aprop ras le cap tot del malaute e pausa sus le coguot de lu emplaustre de cetre descrit en le tractat dels emplastres.	And then shave the patient's entire head and apply to their neck a plaster of cetre [a type of plaster, likely containing a specific ingredient] described in the treatise on plasters.
E pausa aquel alcunas veguadas, quar aquel es manieyra de cauteri.	And apply that several times, for that is a manner of cautery.
E fay aquo segon aquel meteys orde le qual ja he dit.	And do this according to the same order which I have already said.
E donc si per aqueles sanat bo es; e sino, lahoras fay a lu tres cauteris en la deriera partida de sieu cap, les quals sian deysendentz de la partida pus sobirana del cap entro a la partida pus dejos del col.	And therefore if he is healed by these means, it is good; and if not, then make for him three cauterizations in the back part of his head, which descend from the uppermost part of the head down to the lower part of the neck.
E pausa entre quascun cauteri la grossetut del dit, e aprop cura lo cauteri am aquo que es procedit.	And place between each cautery the width of a finger, and then treat the cautery with what has been prescribed.
Mays si tu vos addicio e le malaute es aquo tollerant, lahoras fay a lu cauteri en le mieg loc; e si voys major addicio, lahora cauteriza aquel sobre les dos corns.	But if you add to it and the patient tolerates it, then apply cautery to the middle location; and if you want a greater addition, then cauterize that over the two horns.  (Here "horns" likely refers to a branching or spread-out location related to the initial cautery site).
Aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat; e sia le cauteri olivar segon la forma denant donat.	Then treat that until it is healed; and let the cautery be olive-shaped according to the form given before.
Capitol .ix.	Chapter 9.
De cauterisacio de parazili e de mollificacio de tot le cors.	Concerning the cauterization of paralysis and the softening of the whole body.
Cove que tu procesiscas en mondificacio del cap am jerras e am aquo que havem dit; e aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap, e am cauteri sobre totz les corns del cap, e am cauteri sobre la deriera partida de lu, e am tres cauteris sobre les spondils del col.	That you proceed in the purification of the head with herbs and with that which we have said; and then shave the patient's head, and then cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over all the horns of the head, and with a cautery over the back part of it, and with three cauteries over the vertebrae of the neck.
E si es necessari en la malautia de mollificacio del cors de trops aquel e les malautes tollerantz e la malautia es fort, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris sobre les spondils del dos, e dererament am cauteri entro que sia comborit de la codena mot de lu, e aleva la tieua ma.	And if it is necessary in the illness of softening of the body to find it and the patient tolerates it and the illness is severe, then cauterize it with four cauteries over the vertebrae of the back, and finally with a cautery until it is numb from the burning of it, and raise your hand.
E aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat, e aquest sia cauteri olivar.	And then care for it until it is healed, and this should be an olive cautery.
Capitol .x.	Chapter 10.
De cauterisacio de epilemcia.	Concerning the cauterization of epilepsy.
No es cauterizat le epilemtic sino aquella epilemcia es per flecma.	The epileptic is not cauterized unless that epilepsy is due to phlegm.
E donc cove que mondifiques le cervel de lu al comensament de lu am yeras e am l’autra curacio la qual havem dicta en la divisio quan le malaute es gran e es tollerant la exceperacio de las medicinas.	And therefore it is necessary that you purify his brain at the beginning with herbs and with the other treatments which we have described in the section when the patient is strong and can tolerate the expulsion of medicines.
E si es enfant le qual no sufferte las medicinas, lahoras aministra guarguarissmes e mastiguatoris le servel mondifican, denant aquo per motz dias, am bonifficacio de las viandas.	And if it is a child who cannot tolerate medicines, then administer gargles and masticatories that purify the brain, before that for many days, with the improvement of the diet.
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en le mieg loc del cap segon la manieyra precedent, e am autre cauteri en le occiput de lu, e sobre quascun corn del cap sieu cauterisa.	Then shave the head of the patient, and cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head according to the previous method, and with another cautery on his occiput, and cauterize above each temple.
E si le malaute es fort e es tollerant, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteris les quals he ditz, en havent paraliticament e mollificacio del cors sobre les spondils del col e les spondils del dos.	And if the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I have mentioned, having paralysis and softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck and the vertebrae of the back.
E sia cauteri olivar segon qu’es precedit.	And let the cautery be olive-shaped, as has been previously described.
Mays si le malaute es enfant, lahoras pausa cauteri subtil segon aquesta manieyra.	But if the patient is a child, then apply a small/fine cautery according to this method.
Capitol .xi.	Chapter 11.
De cauterizacio de melencolia.	Concerning the cauterization of melancholia.
Quan las causas de melencolia so humiditatz corrompudas e flacma gros, lahoras cauteriza aquel am les cauteris les quals havem ditz en le havent paralisi.	When the causes of melancholia are corrupt humors and a thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries which we have described in the treatment of paralysis.
E si la causa de melencolia es superfluitat declinant a melencolia, e le cors del malaute es humit, lahoras da ha beure aquo que mundifica le cervel de lu segon aquo que ha precedut en la divisio.	And if the cause of melancholia is a superfluity inclining towards melancholia, and the patient's body is humid, then give him something to drink that cleanses his brain, according to what has preceded in the division (of treatments).
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop fay tortora decentment fayta de li sobre le cercle, e aprop depausa aquela en le mieg loc del cap.	Then shave the patient's head, and then make a properly-made poultice for him on a circle (possibly referring to a bandage or cloth), and then place that in the middle of the head.
E le malaute sia sesent cayrat, e sia tengut de tota partida.	And the patient should be seated upright, and held on all sides (supported).
E aprop pausa liniment; et es pus digne de boder antic de ovelhas.	Then apply a liniment; and it is more worthy (better) to use old sheep's fat.
E escalfa aquel sobre le foc per calefaccio temprada per mesura, le qual le dit sufferta quan es mes en lu.	And heat that over the fire with moderate warmth, which the said sufferer feels when it is applied to him.
E aprop vuo’ aquel en le mieg loc del cap de lu en le cercle, e leysa lu entro que sia enfregidat.	Then pour that into the middle of his head within the circle (bandage), and leave it there until it is cold.
E fay aquo am le malaute en tota semmana una veguada, am le autre regiment de lu bo entro que sia sanat; o si vols, cauteriza aquel fazen petitz puntz segon lo mays de lu, sino que tenguas la ma am un cauteri ayssi ordenat: aquesta es specia de cauteri la qual humecta le cervel am equalitat.	And do this to the patient once a week, with his other treatment, until he is healed; or if you wish, cauterize it making small punctures according to his need, but hold your hand with a cautery thus prepared: this is a kind of cautery which moistens the brain evenly.
E aprop pausa aquel coto enbegut en boder o en grays de gualina.	Then apply that cotton soaked in butter or goose grease.
Capitol .xii.	Chapter 12.
De cauterisacio de aygua descendent en le huel.	On the cauterization of water descending into the eye.
Quan a tu es declarat le comensament de aygua en le huel per les senhals les quals yeu he ditz en la divisio, lahoras comensa e dona en beure al malaute aquo que mondifique le cap de lu, e guarda aquel de totas humiditatz.	When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you by the signs which I have mentioned in the division, then begin and give the patient something to purify his head, and guard him from all humidities.
E fay aquel suzar en banh en degu per alcus jorns.	And make him sweat in a bath for some days.
E aprop comanda a lu que raza le sieu cap, e cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap; e aprop cauteriza aquel am dos cauteris sobre dos templas si es le comensament de ysement de aygua en dos huels, o de la un latz si es comensamen de l’aygua en un huel.	And then order him to shave his head, and cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head; and then cauterize it with two cauteries on the two temples if the beginning of the descent of water is in two eyes, or on one side if the beginning of the water is in one eye.
Incideys am cauteri totas las venas e arcerias las quals so dejos la codena; e sian les cauteris en aquela lonh en la latitut de las templas.	Incise with a cautery all the veins and arteries which are below the occiput (back of the head); and let the cauteries be far apart in the width of the temples.
E guarda te de fluxs de sanc quan es cauterizat; e si veses de lu fluxs de sanc, osta le am alcuna medicina, la qual es a tu possible.	And beware of a flow of blood when it is cauterized; and if you see a flow of blood from it, stop it with some medicine, which is possible for you.
E yeu vindre am savieza la qual es en extraccio de arcerias e am abscizio de aquelas e cautela de fluxs de sanc.	And I come with wisdom which is in the extraction of arteries and with the excision of them and the caution of blood flow.
E alcunas vetz es cauterizat en le cervitz dejos dos osses am dos cauteris dererament produzitz.	And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck below the two bones with two cauteries placed separately.
Capitol .xiii.	Chapter 13.
De cauterizacio de lacrimas antiquas.	Concerning the cauterization of old tears.  (This likely refers to long-standing wounds or sores, using "tears" in a metaphorical sense.)
Quan lacrimas dels huels so antiquas assuduament e per las venas e arterias las quals so en le loc manifest del cap defora e es verificat que aquo es superfluitatz frejas flecmatiquas, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteri le qual havem recontat en le capitol de comensament de aygua cazent en les huels, e am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos templas, e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos osses.	When the tears from the eyes are old and persistent, and through the veins and arteries which are in the manifest area of the head externally, and it is verified that this is a superfluity of cold phlegmatic humors, then cauterize that with the cautery which we have recounted in the beginning chapter about water falling into the eyes, and with a cautery in the middle of the head and with two cauteries in the neck below the two temples, and with two cauteries in the neck below the two bones.
E si indigeyses de addicio, lahoras cauteriza aquel en tot latz de la coa del huel sobre la extremitat del sobrecilh am petit cauteri.	And if it needs additional treatment, then cauterize it in all the area of the corner of the eye above the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
Capitol .xiiii.	Chapter 14.
De cauterizacio de fetor de nas.	Concerning the cauterization of nasal odor (or nasal stench/foul smell).
Quan tu medicas aquel am aquo que havem dit en la divisio e no aprofieyta la tua medicacio, lahoras tu aparelha e dona en beure al malaute las cochias per tres noytz; e aprop ras le cap de lu, e cauteriza le am cauteri migier am cauteri olivar.	When you treat this with what we have said in the section and your treatment is not effective, then you prepare and give the patient  decoctions to drink for three nights; and then shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium-sized cautery, with an olive-shaped cautery.
E aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri clavelh am dos cauteris sobre les dos sobrecilhs dejos les cabels un petit.	And then cauterize that with a clove-shaped cautery, with two cauterizations above the two eyebrows, a little below the hair.
E guarda te de la arceria que no incindas aquela.	And be careful with the cauterization so that you do not burn it.
E del cauteri clavilh aquesta es la forma.	And of the clove-shaped cautery, this is the form/shape.
Capitol .xv.	Chapter 15.
De cauteri de mollificacio de palpebras dels huels.	Of the cauterization for the softening/mollifying of the eyelids.
Quan la palpebra del huel es mollificada per malautia o per humiditat, lahoras cauteriza aquela palpebre1 am un cauteri am aquest cauteri lunar; e aquesta es la forma de lu:	When the eyelid is softened by illness or humidity, then cauterize that eyelid with a lunar cautery; and this is its form:
E si vos, cauteriza aquel sobre les dos sobrecils un petit am dos cauteris en tota partida, e sian elonguatz de las timporas.	And if you cauterize that (area) above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries in each part, and they should be elongated towards the temples.
E sia la longitut de quascun cauteri segon la quantitat del sobrecil.	And let the length of each cautery be according to the size of the eyebrow.
E no premas trop la tua ma am le cauteri, mays segon la quantitat que la tersa partida de la palpebre sia adhurida.	And do not press your hand too much with the cautery, but only to the extent that a third part of the eyelid is hardened/cauterized.
Capitol .xvi.	Chapter 16.
De cauteri de la palpebre del huel quan les pels so convertitz a las partidas dedintz e punho le huel.	Concerning cauterization of the eyelid of the eye when the hairs are turned inwards and prick the eye.
Quan les pels del huel son convertitz a las partidas dedintz ayssi que pungo le huel, cauteri en aquels es segon dos manieyras, quar cauteri o es am fer o es am medicina comburent.	When the hairs of the eye are turned inwards so that they prick the eye, cauterization in these cases is done in two ways, for cauterization is either done with fire or with a burning medicine.
Si am cauteri de lu am foc, comanda al malaute denant aquo que leyse les sieus pels ayssi cum aquels les quals les mundan, entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz; e si punho aquel deves le lor naysement, lahoras tu strenh les huels de lu am una benda per so que no sia maugut entro que·ls pels sian nascutz.	If cauterizing with fire, instruct the patient beforehand to shave their eyelashes like those who cleanse them, until they are long and thick; and if they prick near their roots, then bind the patient's eyes with a bandage so that they are not injured until the eyelashes have grown.
Donc cum siran nascutz e engualhatz, lahoras pausa le cap del malaute en le tieu se, e aprop senha sobre la palpebre dels huels de lu am tenta, am senhal le qual sia segon la figura de fulha de merta, e sia le comensament del senhal prop dels pels.	Then, when they have grown and thickened, place the patient's head in your lap, and then mark on the eyelid of their eyes with a probe, with a mark that is shaped like a myrtle leaf, and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
E aprop pausa coto enbegut en album de huou o en mucillatge de ptilli sobre le huel.	And then place a cotton ball soaked in egg white or in mallow mucilage on the eye.
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma de lu.	And then heat the cautery, whose form is this.
E aprop cauteriza sobre la figura la qual as senhada, petit a petit, em motas veguadas, entro que sia comburida la superficia de la codena la qual es ayssi cum fuelha de mirta, tota aparent propriament.	And then cauterize over the mark that you made, little by little, in many times, until the surface of the eyelid which is like a myrtle leaf is burned, all properly apparent.
E senhal de sanetat de la tieua obra es que tu vegus la palpebre de l’huel ja esser contrayta e·ls pels de lu esser elevatz deves la punctura del huel.	And a sign of the success of your work is that you see the eyelid already contracted and the hairs raised above the puncture of the eye.
E donc eleva la tua ma e laysa aquel per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eredicada la scara.	Then raise your hand and leave it for three days, and then place cotton with a poultice on it until the scar is healed.
E aprop cura aquela am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Mays si retorna per les pels alcuna causa aprop lor naysement e la palpebra es mollificada, lahoras fay autra vetz le cauteri sobre aquel tot ayssi cum avias fayt primieyrament.	But if some matter returns through the hairs near their origin and the eyelid is softened, then perform the cautery again on that area, exactly as you did before.
Mays si les pels so en la palpebra dejos, lahoras cauterisa aquela entro que sia elevada al sieu loc natural e sia engualhat e que les pels no punhan le huelh.	But if the hairs are under the eyelid, then cauterize it until it is raised to its natural place and is even, so that the hairs do not touch the eye.
Mays le cauteri am medicina comburent aquest es que comandes al malaute que leyse les pels entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz, e aprop sia fayta de carta de drap la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	But cauterize with a caustic medicine; this means that you instruct the patient to pull the hairs until they are elongated and even, and then a leaf-shaped piece of linen is applied.
E aprop pren de sabo conogut e de caus viva ana unc. i, o quays aquo, e aprop mescle3 aquelas causas be, e fay aquo am festinacio per so que no sia enfregidat; e aprop expandeys de aquo sobre la carta la qual es fayta ayssi cum forma de fulha de mirtra, e pausa aquel sobre la un huel od amdos; e pausa dejos le huel coto enbegut en album de huou, e el cap del malaute sia en le tieu se.	Then take known soap and quicklime, one ounce, or something like that, and mix these ingredients well, and do this quickly so that it does not get cold; then spread this on the linen shaped like a myrtle leaf, and place this on one or both eyes; and place under the eye a cotton ball soaked in egg white, and the patient's head should be in your lap.
E pausa le dit sobre le medicina e prem aquela un petit e no la mauguas entro que lo malaute senta la mordicacio de la medicina, quar mordicacio es en lu ayssi cum de foc.	And place your finger on the medicine and press it lightly, but do not move it until the patient feels the bite of the medicine, for the bite is like fire.
E donc cum percevera aquo que el atrobo mordicacio, lahoras leyssa la medicina e mau aquela am le tieu dit; donc cum cessa la mordicacio, lahoras remau la medicina he lava le huel am aygua; e lahoras considera si vezes la palpebra ja es levada ayssi cum es lavada deves la costriccio am foc o am incisio, quar lahoras esta be; e si no torna sobre aquela de la medicina sobre le loc en le qual no ha empremut la medicina e no se denigra entro que sia engualhada la tua operacio e sia contrayt le huel.	And when you perceive that he feels the bite, then leave the medicine and move it with your finger; when the bite ceases, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water; and then observe if you see that the eyelid is raised as it should be, relieved of the constriction by fire or incision, for then it is well; and if not, return to applying the medicine to the place where the medicine has not yet been applied and it does not darken until your work is even and the eye is contracted.
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eradicada la codena de la adhustio, e aprop cura aquel am enguent deafinicon o am autre entro que sia sanat.	Then place cotton with a bandage on it until the scab from the cauterization is gone, and then treat it with healing ointment or something else until it is healed.
E es necessari a tu, deves la tua operacio que guardes am pervigil diligencia que en le huel no caia re de la medicina, e si la palpebre aprop alscus dias es mollificada e alcuna causa dels pels punh en le huel, lahoras itera la tua medicina sobre aquel loc le qual de la palpebre es mollificat, e propriamen ayssi quo as fayt al comensament, e aprop enaviro lu entro que sia sanat.	And it is necessary for you, during your operation, to watch with vigilant diligence that nothing of the medicine falls into the eye, and if the eyelid after a few days is softened and some hair grows in the eye, then repeat your medicine on that part of the eyelid which is softened, and exactly as you did in the beginning, and then bandage it until it is healed.
E aquesta es la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	And this is the form of myrtle leaf. (Referring to a shape or method described previously, likely a shape for applying medicine or a bandage)
E sapias que les huels dels homes son diversificatz segon la magnitut e la parvitat, e donc segon aquo es fayta la tua contraccio.	And know that the eyes of men are diverse in size, both large and small, and therefore your constriction (or perhaps contraction/adjustment) should be made accordingly.
E no sira amaguada la via de rectetut ad aquel al qual es studi en aquesta art.	And the path of righteousness will not be hidden from him who studies this art. (This is a metaphorical statement implying that proper technique will be revealed to the diligent student).
Capitol .xvii.	Chapter 17.
De cauterizacio de fistula que es en le lacrimal de l’huel.	Concerning the cauterization of a fistula that is in the tear duct of the eye.
Quan tu curas fistula am aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias e no confereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas aquela segon aquesta manieyra: comanda al malaute que pause le cap sieu en le tieu se, e tengua le cap de lu alcun ministre entre las tieuas mas en tal manieyra que no sia maugut ni agitat am le sieu cap.	When you treat a fistula with what we have mentioned in the divisions of diseases and your treatment is not successful, then you must cauterize it in this manner: instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and let a minister hold his head between your hands in such a way that his head is not moved or shaken.
E aprop pausa coto enfus en album de huou o en mucellage de ptilli sobre le huel de lu.	Then place cotton soaked in egg white or gum arabic on his eye.
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	And then heat the cautery, whose shape is this:
le qual sia conquau, ayssi cum es forma de cana o de pena de voltor, de la una extremitat am la qual es fayta lo cauteri.	which should be concave, like the shape of a cane or a vulture's feather, at the end with which the cauterization is performed.
E si voys, sia penetrant entro a la autra extremitat.	And if you wish, let it be penetrating to the other extremity.
E si vols sia sort ayssi cum tenta.	And if you wish, let it be sharp like a probe.
Mays empero aquel que es concau es milhor a la tieua obra.	However, the concave one is better for your work.
E aprop prem la fistula si es uberta, e tra de lu sania et exsicca aquela.	Then press the fistula if it is open, and draw out the pus and dry it.
E si no es uberta, lahoras obre aquela e extratz la poyredura de lu.	And if it is not open, then open it and extract the pus from it.
E aprop pausa sobre lu le cauteri le qual sia be ignit, e te am aquel la tieua ma un petit deves le cauteri del huel a la partida del nas, per so que no erre la tua ma o le malaute sia enquietat, e lahoras pausa le cauteri en le grays del huel e corrompas aquel.	Then place over it the cautery, which should be well ignited, and hold your hand a little below the cautery, from the eye to the side of the nose, so that your hand does not waver or the patient is disturbed, and then place the cautery on the granulation of the eye and cauterize it.
E donc si al comensament del tieu cauteri perve entro al os, bo es; e sino, lahoras itera le cauteri una veguada o dos, si mestiers era; e layssa aquel ayssi per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre aquel coto am boder e enviro lu am enguent exsiccatiu entro que sia sanat.	And so if at the beginning your cautery penetrates to the bone, it is good; and if not, then repeat the cautery once or twice, if necessary; and leave it like that for three days, and then apply a bandage over it with a drying ointment until it is healed.
Mays si eran passatz xi dias e no es sanat, lahoras pausa sobre lu medicina aguda corrosiva entro que l’os sia descubert e sia ras segon que conveneys en le sieu capitol.	But if ten days have passed and it is not healed, then apply a sharp, corrosive medicine until the bone is exposed and scraped as is appropriate in its chapter.
E es autra manieyra de cauteri de fistula la qual alscus primiers diysero: enten al loc de la fistula e fen aquela e aprop pausa en aquela fissura camaen subtil del qual es la forma de lu: E fon en aquela la quantitat de i unc de plom fundut; e te la tua ma am camaem am bona retencio, e no sia maugut le malaute per so que le plom fundut no pervengua al huel de aquel; e cove que pausas sobre le huel del malaute coto enfus en album de huou o en aygua, quar plom adhureys le loc de la fistula e sana aquela per sanacio meravilhora.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula which some ancients mentioned: approach the location of the fistula and open it, and then place in that fissure a thin tube, which is shaped like this:  And pour into it the quantity of one ounce of molten lead; and hold your hand with a cloth with good retention, and the patient should not be moved so that the molten lead does not reach his eye; and it is necessary to place over the patient’s eye a cloth soaked in egg white or water, for the lead adheres to the location of the fistula and heals it with marvelous healing.
E si la fistula es sanada am aquo que havem dit del cauteri e de la curacio, bo es; e sino, lahoras es necessari aministrar trauc del nas e reduzir la fistula al cors del nas segon que vindra en son loc propri.	And if the fistula is healed with what we have said about the cautery and the treatment, it is good; and if not, then it is necessary to make an opening in the nose and reduce the fistula to the body of the nose according to where it will return to its proper place.
Capitol .xviii.	Chapter 18.
De cauterizacio de la fendedura des potz.	Concerning the cauterization of the cleft of the well (likely referring to a fissure or wound).
Motas veguadas accideysso fissuras en las labias, e majorment en las labias dels enfantz.	Often fissures occur on the lips, and especially on the lips of children.
Donc cum tu curas aquelas fissuras am aquo que nos havem dit en las divisios e no aprofieyta la tua cura, lahoras igneys le cauteri petit cutellar segon aquesta forma que s’ensiec:	Therefore, if you treat those fissures with what we have said in the divisions and your treatment is not effective, then ignite a small, knife-like cautery according to this form which is shown:
E sia la conquavitat de lu segon la subtilitat de cotella.	And let its concavity be according to the subtlety of a knife.
Aprop pausa aquel init cuytadament en aquelas fissuras entro que·l cauteri pervengua al preon de las fissuras.	Then carefully place that ignited cautery into those fissures until the cautery reaches the bottom of the fissures.
E aprop cura aquel am cerotz entro que sia sanat.	Then treat it with cerates until it is healed.
Capitol .xix.	Chapter 19.
De cauterizacio de fistula en la boca.	Concerning the cauterization of a fistula in the mouth.
Quan en la razit de uvula o en le paladar o en las razitz de las dentz endeve apostema e aprop fa brac, e aprop es rompuda, e aprop es antiquada, e corr brac e es fayta fistula, e aprop tu curas aquela e no aprofieyta a curacio, lahoras cove que tu igniscas cauteri segon la quantitat que sia receubuda en la fistula, e aprop met aquel ignit en le trauc de la fistola, e te la tua ma entro que pervengua le ferr ignit al preon de lu, e al derier de lu fazen aysso una veguada o dos; e aprop cura aquel am aquo que nos havem dit de la curacio entro que sia sanat.	When in the root of the uvula, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth, an abscess develops and then breaks, and then becomes chronic, and pus flows and a fistula is formed, and you treat it and the treatment is ineffective, then you should ignite a cautery according to the size of the fistula, and then place that ignited cautery into the opening of the fistula, holding it with your hand until the heated iron reaches the bottom of it, and afterwards do this once or twice; and then treat it with what we have said about treatment until it is healed.
E donc si la sania es abscindita e es sanat, bo es; e sino, lahoras es necessari de descubrir le loc e hostar le os corrumput segon que vindra en son capitol.	And so if the wound is excised and heals, it is good; but if not, then it is necessary to expose the area and remove the corrupted bone according to what will be found in its chapter.
Capitol .xx.	Chapter 20.
De cauterisacio de las dentz e de mollificacio de las angivas.	Concerning the cauterization of the teeth and the softening of the gums.
Quan las angivas son mollificadas per humiditat e las dentz son maugudas, e curas aquelas am medicinas e no confereys, lahoras pausa le cap del malaute en le tieu se, e aprop igneys le cauteri la forma del qual vindra aprop aysso, enayssi que tu pauses la quanula sobre la dent e entromet en aquela le cauteri ignit festinantment, e te la tieua ma un petit entro que·l malaute cente la calor del foc a la razit de la dent esser pervenguda.	When the gums are softened by moisture and the teeth are loose, and you treat them with medicines and they don't help, then place the patient's head in your lap, and then heat the cautery—the shape of which will be appropriate for this—in such a way that you place the small cup (or shield) over the tooth and quickly insert the heated cautery into it, and hold it a little while until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
E aprop leva la tua ma, e aprop itera le cauteri alcunas veguadas segon que vols.	And then remove your hand, and then repeat the cauterization a few times as needed.
E aprop le malaute huompla la sua boca de aygua de sal e tengua aquela per una hora, e pueys stupa aquela, quar la dent mauguda es fermada e la gengiva mollificada es strenguda e la humiditat corrompuda es exsiccada.	And then let the patient fill their mouth with salt water and hold it for an hour, and then spit it out, because the loose tooth is fixed, the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupt moisture is dried.
Capitol .xxi.	Chapter 21.
De cauterisacio de dolor de dent.	On the cauterization of toothache.
Quan dolor de dent es per fregiditat, o en lu es freg o verm, o no comfereys la curacio am medicina, lahoras cauteri en aquela es segon dos manieyras: o cauteri am boder de vacas, o cauteri am foc.	When toothache is due to coldness, or if there is cold or worms in it, and you cannot cure it with medicine, then cauterization is done in two ways: either cauterization with a hot iron, or cauterization with fire.
Cauteri am boder es que tu prenguas boder de vacas e bulhas aquel en culhe de ferr , e aprop pren coto e envolopa le sobre la extremitat de la tenta, e aprop enmergeys aquel am boder bulhit, e pausa aquel sobre la dent dolorosa festinantment entro que sia enfregidat.	Cauterization with a hot iron is that you take a hot iron and heat it in a fire, and then take cotton and wrap it around the end of the probe, and then dip it in the boiling iron, and apply it to the painful tooth quickly until it is cooled.
E aprop itera aquela alcunas veguadas entro que la vertut del foc pervengua a la razit de la dentz.	And then repeat this several times until the power of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
E si voys, submergeys lana o coto en le boder desus dit, e pausa aquel sobre la dent dolent, e pausa sobre aquel ferr ignit entro que·l ferr pervengua al preon de la conquavitat de la dent.	And if you wish, dip wool or cotton in the aforementioned hot iron, and place that on the aching tooth, and place a glowing iron on top of that until the iron reaches the bottom of the tooth cavity.
Mays empero la cauterizacio am foc es que tu atendas a la quannula de eram o de ferr, e sia en le cor de lu alcuna grocesa e la acuitat del foc no pervengua a la boca del malaute.	However, cauterization with fire is that you use a small tube of brass or iron, and there should be some thickness in its core so that the intensity of the fire does not reach the patient's mouth.
E aprop igneys le cauteri la forma del qual vindra, e pausa aquel sobre la dent e te la tua ma entro que·l cauteri sia enfregidat; e fay aquo alcunas veguadas quar la dolor sira remauguda o en aquel dia o en l’autre dia.	Then ignite the cautery, shaping it as needed, and place it on the tooth, holding your hand there until the cautery cools; and do this several times because the pain will be relieved either that day or the next.
E cove que per empressio de aquel cauteri que·l malaute umpla la sieua boca de bon boder e tengua aquel per una hora e aprop scupa le; e aquesta es la forma del cauteri.	And it is necessary that, upon application of that cautery, the patient fill their mouth with good hot water and hold it for an hour, and then spit it out; and this is the method of cauterization.
E cauteriza am qual que tu voys extremittat segon que a tu es possible.	And cauterize with whichever extremity you wish, as is possible for you.
E aquesta es la forma de la cannula:	And this is the form of the cannula:
Capitol .xxii.	Chapter 22.
De cauterizacio de extrophulos.	Concerning the cauterization of extrophuli (likely referring to a type of skin lesion or protrusion).
